remarks: Any nonzero ordinal ` B ` is equinumerous to the leading term of its Cantor normal form.  (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 30-May-2015.) Obsolete version of ~ cnfcom2 as of 3-Jul-2019. (New usage is discouraged.)  (Proof modification is discouraged.)
statement:
cnfcomOLD.s $e |- S = dom ( _om CNF A ) $.
cnfcomOLD.a $e |- ( ph -> A e. On ) $.
cnfcomOLD.b $e |- ( ph -> B e. ( _om ^o A ) ) $.
cnfcomOLD.f $e |- F = ( `' ( _om CNF A ) ` B ) $.
cnfcomOLD.g $e |- G = OrdIso ( _E , ( `' F " ( _V \ 1o ) ) ) $.
cnfcomOLD.h $e |- H = seqom ( ( k e. _V , z e. _V |-> ( M +o z ) ) , (/) ) $.
cnfcomOLD.t $e |- T = seqom ( ( k e. _V , f e. _V |-> K ) , (/) ) $.
cnfcomOLD.m $e |- M = ( ( _om ^o ( G ` k ) ) .o ( F ` ( G ` k ) ) ) $.
cnfcomOLD.k $e |- K = ( ( x e. M |-> ( dom f +o x ) ) u. `' ( x e. dom f |-> ( M +o x ) ) ) $.
cnfcomOLD.w $e |- W = ( G ` U. dom G ) $.
cnfcom2OLD.1 $e |- ( ph -> (/) e. B ) $.
cnfcom2OLD $p |- ( ph -> ( T ` dom G ) : B -1-1-onto-> ( ( _om ^o W ) .o ( F ` W ) ) ) $.
